deliberation: Considered whether this standard prophetic formula is purely literal or uses figurative devices. The phrase treats YHWH’s “word” as a quasi-entity that moves toward the prophet, and uses “word” metonymically for revelation. I therefore treat the whole clause as one conventional idiomatic expression combining metonymy and personification.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me:
vehicle: “the word of YHWH” coming to the prophet
a spoken word treated as a moving entity that approaches someone
ground: God’s initiative in sending a specific, directed message to Ezekiel
posture: presents Ezekiel’s message as directly originating from YHWH and therefore authoritative
authorization / legitimation of the prophetic speech
instances.explanation: “Word of YHWH” stands metonymically for God’s revelatory message, and this ‘word’ is personified as something that can ‘come’ to the prophet—an idiomatic prophetic way of portraying revelation.

deliberation: The vine image here still functions on the literal level of the mashal (parable); its figurative application to Jerusalem only becomes explicit in verse 6. The clearly non-literal element is the vocative בֶּן־אָדָם, which functions idiomatically for “mortal / human” and highlights Ezekiel’s humanity.

target: Ezekiel understood as a finite human being
vehicle: “son of man” as a descendant of humankind
ground: shared human nature and limitation in contrast to God
posture: addresses and humbles the prophet by emphasizing his mere humanity before divine speech
humbling vocative in a prophetic address
instances.explanation: “Son of man” is an idiomatic metonymy for a human being, emphasizing creaturely, mortal status rather than literal parentage.

deliberation: Although this verse belongs to a parabolic discourse, its wording simply describes what one literally can or cannot do with vine wood. No explicit or implicit non-literal transfer (to Israel/Jerusalem) is made in this verse itself, and no stock idioms or anthropomorphisms appear.

The verse continues the literal description of the vine wood’s behavior in fire within the mashal. Fire consuming the ends and charring the middle is a realistic scenario. The figurative application to Jerusalem’s fate is still not stated here, so at the level of wording the expressions are literal, not independent metaphors or idioms.

This line further develops the practical uselessness of vine wood even before and certainly after burning. The assertions concern the physical properties of such wood and remain within the literal source domain of the parable; no separate figurative idioms, personifications, or explicit comparisons to people are introduced in this verse.

Here the figurative mapping is finally made explicit: the previous description of vine wood becomes a vehicle for describing Jerusalem. The clause introduced by כַּאֲשֶׁר … כֵּן forms a clear simile comparing Jerusalem’s inhabitants to useless vine wood destined for burning.

instances.hebrew_text: כַּאֲשֶׁ֤ר עֵץ־הַגֶּ֙פֶן֙ בְּעֵ֣ץ הַיַּ֔עַר אֲשֶׁר־נְתַתִּ֥יו לָאֵ֖שׁ לְאׇכְלָ֑ה כֵּ֣ן נָתַ֔תִּי אֶת־יֹשְׁבֵ֖י יְרוּשָׁלִָֽם
instances.english_text: Like the wood of the grapevine among the trees of the forest, which I have designated to be fuel for fire, so will I treat the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
target: the inhabitants of Jerusalem under divine judgment
vehicle: vine wood among forest trees given to the fire for consumption
low‑quality, unserviceable wood suitable only for burning
ground: their lack of perceived usefulness and their suitability only for destruction
posture: casts Jerusalem in a sharply negative light, justifying their coming destruction by likening them to useless vine wood
instances.explanation: The inhabitants of Jerusalem are explicitly compared (with כַּאֲשֶׁר … כֵּן) to useless vine wood that is fit only to be burned, highlighting their moral worthlessness and destiny of destruction.

deliberation: This verse contains two distinct figurative elements: (1) the anthropomorphic idiom “I will set my face against them” for God’s hostile stance, and (2) the ‘fire’ from which they escape and by which they are later ‘eaten/consumed,’ which functions as a metaphor (with personifying language) for devastating judgment rather than only literal flames.

instances.english_text: I will set My face against them
target: YHWH’s hostile stance toward the people
vehicle: turning or setting one’s face against someone
physical orientation of a human face expressing opposition
posture: presents God’s judgment as intensely personal and resolute, not impersonal misfortune
intensification of threat through anthropomorphic imagery
instances.explanation: God’s attitude of judgment is described anthropomorphically as ‘setting [his] face against’ the people, an idiom drawing on human bodily behavior to express divine hostility.

instances.english_text: they escaped from fire, but fire shall consume them
target: the people’s earlier and forthcoming experiences of calamity and judgment
vehicle: escaping one fire yet being consumed by another fire
literal conflagration that can burn and ‘eat’ victims
ground: the inescapable, devouring nature of the coming punishment
posture: underscores the inevitability and thoroughness of divine judgment, even for those who survived earlier troubles
instances.explanation: ‘Fire’ here functions as a metaphor (and is personified as something that can ‘eat/consume’ them) for devastating judgment—likely war and destruction—from which some previously escaped but which will ultimately overtake them.

deliberation: The statement about making the land a desolation because of trespass describes the covenant curse in straightforward terms. ‘Land’ most naturally refers to the actual territory, and ‘desolation’ to real ruin; no idiomatic or metaphorical wording beyond standard legal–prophetic diction is evident.
